## Verified on sonic-vs VM

**Environment:** SONiC master (fcf18f7e0), Python 3.13.5, Debian 13.3

**Bug reproduction (unpatched):**
```
>>> sysmon.check_unit_status("sys-devices-pci0000:00-0000:00:1f.0.device")
ValueError: too many values to unpack (expected 2)
```

**Fix verification (patched `rsplit(".", 1)`):**
```
PASS multi-dot device sys-devices-pci0000:00-0000:00:1f.0.device
PASS multi-dot mount dev-disk-by\x2did-wwn\x2d0x5001.mount
PASS single-dot mount run-user-1000.mount
PASS normal service mock_bgp.service
PASS timer unit mock_snmp.timer
```

## Test Results — SONIC_BUILD_MEMORY_FLAGS

Tested both Makefile logic expansion and Docker runtime behavior.

### Makefile Logic Tests (6/6 pass)

Using a test harness that copies the exact `SONIC_BUILD_MEMORY_FLAGS` logic from `Makefile.work`:

| # | Scenario | Expected | Result |
|---|----------|----------|--------|
| 1 | `SONIC_BUILD_MEMORY` unset (default) | No `--memory` flag | ✅ PASS |
| 2 | `SONIC_BUILD_MEMORY=24g` | `--memory=24g` | ✅ PASS |
| 3 | `SONIC_BUILD_MEMORY=24g` + `SONIC_BUILD_MEMORY_SWAP=48g` | Both flags | ✅ PASS |
| 4 | `SONIC_BUILD_MEMORY=none` (explicit disable) | No `--memory` flag | ✅ PASS |
| 5 | Memory flag placement | Before `-e http_proxy` | ✅ PASS |
| 6 | `SONIC_BUILDER_EXTRA_CMDLINE` stays last | `--cpus=4` at end | ✅ PASS |

### Docker Runtime Tests (4/4 pass)

| # | Scenario | Expected | Result |
|---|----------|----------|--------|
| 7 | `--memory=128m` → cgroup limit | `134217728` (128MB) | ✅ PASS |
| 8 | No `--memory` → unlimited | `max` | ✅ PASS |
| 9 | OOM contained in container | Exit 137 (SIGKILL), host unaffected | ✅ PASS |
| 10 | `--memory=128m --memory-swap=128m` | memory=128MB, swap=0 | ✅ PASS |

All 10 tests pass. The feature works as designed: opt-in memory limit, OOM kills stay inside the container, and `SONIC_BUILDER_EXTRA_CMDLINE` can still override.

## Integration Test — Build-Like Workload Under Memory Constraint

Simulated a real build scenario: compile + run a memory-hungry process inside a Docker container, with and without `--memory`.

### Test Setup
- Container image: `debian:bookworm-slim` + `build-essential`
- Workload: `make` builds and runs a C program that allocates 10MB chunks until OOM
- Host: 30GB RAM

### Results

**Test A — WITHOUT `--memory` (current behavior):**
```
Allocated 13560MB
Allocated 13570MB
...
Allocated 13630MB
```
Process consumed **13.6GB** of host RAM before being externally killed (timeout). Without the timeout, it would eat all 30GB and trigger the **kernel OOM killer**, which can kill **any** host process — including your desktop, SSH sessions, or other builds.

**Test B — WITH `--memory=64m` (this PR):**
```
Allocated 40MB
Allocated 50MB
...
Allocated 120MB
make: 2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023 2024 2025 2026 parse_reviews.py pr_dump.sh repo_list.sh repos update.sh [Makefile:3: all] Killed
Exit code: 137 (SIGKILL from cgroup OOM)
```
Process OOM-killed at the container boundary. Host unaffected.

**Test C — Host verification after OOM:**
```
 total used free
Mem: 30Gi 7.8Gi 14Gi
```
Host RAM untouched.

### Kernel Log Confirmation
```
oom-kill:constraint=CONSTRAINT_MEMCG,...task=mem_hog,pid=76693
Memory cgroup out of memory: Killed process 76693 (mem_hog) total-vm:135648kB, anon-rss:61248kB
```
The kill was triggered by `CONSTRAINT_MEMCG` (Docker cgroup limit) — **not** the system-wide OOM killer. This is exactly the behavior the PR enables: OOM stays contained inside the build container.

Thanks for the review @saiarcot895 — all good points.

Updated the PR:
- **Dropped the bullseye changes** — agreed it's no longer used.
- **Dropped the bookworm Dockerfile change** — Python 3.11 isn't affected by the `imp` removal.
- **Kept prerequisites.sh scoped** — the host may run Python 3.12+. The script already preferred jinjanator with j2cli as fallback, so I just fixed `apt install` → `apt-get install -y` (non-interactive) and added a PATH hint for pip `--user` installs.

Agreed that jinjanator is the right long-term choice over Debian's j2cli packaging.

@Pterosaur @r12f 
This change will make countersyncd run regardless to whether or not HFT is even configured.
This will waste resources when HFT is disabled.

Also the way that it is set, countersyncd will always run with only enable-otel flag. The service countersyncd also provides flags such as otel-endpoint or otel-capacity flags - which are not configurable by this implementation.

I suggested to keep it as a service that will only start in response to a CLI command by the user or a DB configuration
Azure Pipelines successfully started running 1 pipeline(s).

> @Pterosaur @r12f This change will make countersyncd run regardless to whether or not HFT is even configured. This will waste resources when HFT is disabled.
> 
> Also the way that it is set, countersyncd will always run with only enable-otel flag. The service countersyncd also provides flags such as otel-endpoint or otel-capacity flags - which are not configurable by this implementation.
> 
> I suggested to keep it as a service that will only start in response to a CLI command by the user or a DB configuration

Hi @DavidZagury Thanks for your suggestion
1. It's impossible to connect the CLI with the countersyncd service. Because we have multiple methods to config HFT. Cli is just one of them. In the most time, we will use GNMI to config it which means the GNMI will directly inject configuration into config db instead of using CLI.
2. In my humble opinion, if there is no data telemetry traffic under the countersyncd which means the HFT feature isn't enabled or configured, the countersyncd will be almost silent. It will only use tens of megabytes of memory and almost zero CPU.
3. To the flag `otel-endpoint`, it's not a standard method to configure the endpoint of otel. The better way is to use the config db that mentioned in: https://github.com/sonic-net/SONiC/blob/master/doc/high-frequency-telemetry/high-frequency-telemetry-hld.md#742-high_frequency_telemetry_profile But we haven't supported that. This flag is exposed right now that is only used for simplifying testing flow.

hi @lipxu could you help to clarify what does the datastore lock for in the description? And why we could take it as a signal of mgmtd initial config done?

> hi @lipxu could you help to clarify what does the datastore lock for in the description? And why we could take it as a signal of mgmtd initial config done?

Thanks Storm, The datastore lock is used to prevent other processes from accessing the datastore while mgmtd is using it.
During startup, mgmtd acquires the datastore lock and releases it only after the initial configuration load is complete.
Therefore, if the script reports that the datastore is not locked, it is safe to assume that mgmtd has finished its initial configuration.

> > @wumiaont can you clarify benefit of adding this in show output. Does each vendor need to define fips module name in platform file.
> 
> @judyjoseph FIPS certificate will list the macsec FIPS module name on the certificate. FIPS lab required SONiC to have a CLI command to display the macsec FIPS module name so security officer in the data center can check the deployed system is running the same module as FIPS certificate shows.
> 
> Yes. This FIPS module name is vendor specific. Each vendor can provide this name in the vendor specific platform.json and this CLI will display it. If vendor doesn't provide it will have no output for this command.

Sure, so so this name "Nokia-SONiC-MACsec-Version 1.0" signify something? (like a particular version of SAI macsec library, ssl library etc )

> Nokia-SONiC-MACsec-Version 1.0

Nokia-SONiC-MACsec-Version 1.0 is the name for the FIPS module on Nokia chassis. This includes software (BCOM SDK 6.5.34 FIPS module) + hardware (BCOM J2c+ 88852 chip). This name will be put in the certificate and future security officer uses this CLI command to check chassis to make sure it runs with the exact FIPS module.
